hints_html:
Do both operations \(QR\), \(RQ\) have the same effect on all vectors in \(R^{2}\)?

The statement is not true. Try to find a counter example.
hints_latex:
Do both operations $QR$, $RQ$ have the same effect on all vectors in
$R^{2}$?
The statement is not true. Try to find a counter example.
hints_raw:
Do both operations <math>QR</math>, <math>RQ</math> have the same effect on all vectors in <math>R^{2}</math>?
The statement is not true. Try to find a counter example.
question: A 19
sols_html:
Consider a vector, v, that lies on the line \(y = x\).

Applying \(QR\) to this vector will first rotate the vector so that it lies parallel to the \(y\)-axis, then reflect the vector over \(y = x\) so that it lies parallel to the \(x\)-axis.

Applying \(RQ\) to this vector will first reflect the vector over the line \(y = x\), leaving it unchanged, then will rotate the vector so that it lies parallel to the \(y\)-axis.

By this example, \(QR\) and \(RQ\) have different effects on v and thus do not commute. i.e:

\[\begin{aligned} QR \ne RQ.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Consider a vector, v, that lies on the line $y = x$.

Applying $QR$ to this vector will first rotate the vector so that it
lies parallel to the $y$-axis, then reflect the vector over $y = x$ so
that it lies parallel to the $x$-axis.

Applying $RQ$ to this vector will first reflect the vector over the line
$y = x$, leaving it unchanged, then will rotate the vector so that it
lies parallel to the $y$-axis.

By this example, $QR$ and $RQ$ have different effects on v and thus do
not commute. i.e:

\begin{align*}
QR \ne RQ.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Consider a vector, <b>v</b>,  that lies on the line <math>y = x</math>. 

Applying <math>QR</math> to this vector will first rotate the vector so that it lies parallel to the <math>y</math>-axis, then reflect the vector over <math>y = x</math> so that it lies parallel to the <math>x</math>-axis.

Applying <math>RQ</math> to this vector will first reflect the vector over the line <math>y = x</math>, leaving it unchanged, then will rotate the vector so that it lies parallel to the <math>y</math>-axis.

By this example, <math>QR</math> and <math>RQ</math> have different effects on <b>v</b> and thus do not commute. i.e:

:<math>QR \ne RQ</math>.
statement_html: If \(R\) is the 2D counter-clockwise rotation by \(\pi/4\) and \(Q\) is the 2D reflection through the line \(y = x\), is \(QR = RQ\)? Justify briefly.
statement_latex:
If $R$ is the 2D counter-clockwise rotation by $\pi/4$ and $Q$ is the 2D
reflection through the line $y = x$, is $QR = RQ$? Justify briefly.
statement_raw: If <math>R</math> is the 2D counter-clockwise rotation by <math>\pi/4</math> and <math>Q</math> is the 2D reflection through the line <math>y = x</math>, is <math>QR = RQ</math>? Justify briefly.
